text: all right well good morning for me good afternoon
and possibly good evening my name is brian randall and i'll be your host and presenter for this talk on devops
for your relational database foundations now a little bit about
myself i've been doing this a long time i view the world uh from the standpoint an application without a database isn't
very interesting uh you'll find my contact information on the slides and i will uh post a link to the slides
in the slack channel for a track four um a little later this morning or today
so let's just get right into this and make sure we're level set on the concept of devops right we think
about what is devops there's lots of different definitions wikipedia has one but i'm really fond of
this definition which comes from donovan brown at microsoft and we talk about
how devops is made up of this union of three key things people process and products with an
ultimate goal of delivering value to your end users and so
when i work with organizations on devops in general or focused on the database
it's always important to understand that the root thing to work on is the way people interact together
so that people and process thing you can't buy devops in a box it doesn't just magically appear because you use a
particular product or set of products now understand that a holistic set of
products working together can make the difference in how you do things in particular
the making the decision to buy versus build can be critical in those aspects as
we are in 2021 we're very lucky in that we have a rich
set of tools available to us both that are available from commercial vendors but also from the open source
community to where you should always be able to find something that can help you with your devops
transformation and journey without necessarily having to build your own tools building your own tools is often the
siren song that developers get into and it cannot be a mistake and in the case of database devops i've
seen a lot of that over my career when you think about devops it's key to
understand that it's a journey not a destination in fact devops tends to follow uh j
curve when people first get started with it they're really excited you get some quick wins and then there's that slog as
you try and get to the more far-reaching problems that are both organizational and technical
so the thing i'll encourage you is just to always keep this in the back your mind right sometimes you'll go faster
sometimes you'll go slower but it's a continual process of improvement
now at this point right there there's a lot more i could talk about devops concepts or precepts but this is
more of a tactical presentation so i'm gonna assume that you understand that you
gotta work on the people and and process right we often say that you know devops is that second decade of agile and so agile
processes scale to organizations is where it gets very complex but one of the things we need to do then
is we know that tools come last but a technological win
can help really kick off the journey one things i do working with microsoft and github as a partner
is i go to companies and do an engagement called a fast track and as part of the fast track engagement
we try and pick something that's a combination of technical and process to improve
over two weeks and our goal is to show how that type of smaller win can
have a bigger impact on the organization so in this talk we're going to do just
that and talk about how we can have an end-to-end process for our database
that we might already have for our source code c sharp java php
go whatever and what we want to do is set up an end-to-end pipeline that allows
developers that are focused on databases to check in their changes
to source control and have the same workflow we've hopefully already been doing for
10 15 years in our organizations where we do continuous integration
which at a minimum is a process where we go through and validate the input from the developer with other
developers and go for that the simplest of things doesn't compile
beyond that hopefully we're embracing other things like running unit tests
and then once we have the output of the build we can use some type of release management technology
to then take the database and deploy it to shared dev environments local devs
testing and ultimately possibly production all with an automated end-to-end
pipeline now databases are a funny thing because not only do we have this definition of
the structure the catalog we have data in there so databases
introduce their own complexity in this process but the biggest mistake that i see out
there is a bunch of developers working on a shared database just making changes without any
process and without version control and then relying upon either homegrown tools or the very basic of available tools
to get the changes from that shared dumb environment into their various production environments
so we want to do this how well we're going to look at this using
changes to a database through an indian pipeline and we're going to start with that inner loop of just the developer
and then we'll move out to the larger scale pipeline now i'm going to use the sql server data tools that come
inside visual studio 2019 the acronym is ssdt that you'll hear
used and we use azure devops pipelines understand though that there are other tools available and
the basic concepts apply to all relational databases it just might vary based upon the tools
you use to actually get the mechanics down for example redgate has a number of commercial tools available for both sql
server and uh with their uh acquisition of flyway they're actually supporting a lot of
other vendors including oracle for example octopus deploy is a rich set of tools
for doing deployments github has github actions so understand
that while i am going to use the microsoft toolset with sql server and azure devops you can mix and match as you see fit but
going back to that diagram the same concept is going to apply we want a version controller database we
want to have some kind of build validation process and we want to use automated deployments to have a repeatable
process to get our changes out into our various environments
now when coming up with tools and technologies to do this there's kind of two approaches one is
the model approach and this is what ssdt takes
the idea is that we're going to take the catalog or the definition of the database
offline and use a state model we're going to express that model in the form of ddl entities
that's what we're going to work with so rather than using say a graphical tool to manage the changes to a table
we can do that with create table statements and by breaking down our database into
this set of ddl files we have these individual entities that we can then check in and check out of version
control whether it be something like svn tfvc or what i'm going to use get
now the way ssdt works is you have a project inside visual studio with all of
these files organized as you see fit and then you publish your changes by comparing
that model to your target if the target doesn't have the database
at all then it has to create everything on the other hand if it sees that
there are existing objects it will go through and build an in-memory diff of the
target and the model to figure out what changes need to happen this is sometimes referred to as this
golden schema approach we want to take our definition of the model and apply it to the database now from a
mechanical standpoint this can be done with what are called backpack files or you can actually generate sql scripts
and i'll turn on both so you can see that the idea with models and the database is
that you're expressing what the database should be and we're using the tools
to get it forward another approach however is known as migrations um in the
dotnet world ef core is an example of what this is uh but other orms or object relational mappers do
this the idea is that we're going to express via sql migration files that are played back in
a sequence and basically we're able to walk up look at the database and there's usually some
type of version table that says the database is at this migration and the system will say okay i've got
ten possible migrations the database is at five so i'm gonna playback migration six then
seven then eight nine ten until i get it to the level you want
the whole point here is we're migrating changes from the model in a stepwise basis now
this is different from the model approach in that it expresses how your database should change and it
provides a more logical view neither mechanism is better than the
other they all have their pros and cons and success with both is often your comfort
with the tool set and how you change your database but another thing that affects it is
the considerations i want to bring up and this is probably one of the key takeaways because this is where the devil and the details exist
with database devops the first thing to understand is this notification of people in process and getting everybody on the
same page one of the most common aspects you'll run into is drift
between your offline model that you're managing and version control and the target of the change this
particular will run into when you have separate teams that work on applications and the database
versus a team that is responsible for managing or maintaining that database
dbas sometimes are reticent to allow automation into the database
they're responsible for keeping the database safe protecting not only the structure but the data
in addition they may be responsible for actively managing the database while it's online
and so we have to take into consideration that drift where what we think the database should look like
when we go to apply the changes someone's made a change using some other tooling
and we're not in sync and once again that often happens when you have a demarcation line between dev
and production that you don't really communicate well with or it's it's a more traditional siloed
approach and so it goes back to that whole people in processing
the secondary aspect that you have to be aware of is multiple apps using the same database
where we need to coordinate changes between them one of the things that i've seen success
with for teams that are trying to a use a devops process use an automated
pipeline is to create a v team around the database changes and manage those
independently of the application so that when someone needs a change they have to have this in the database
it's brought to the v team the change is made there and then the application is able to pick it up this prevents a lot of chaos that occurs
in changing this foundational structure that also introduces a little subtlety in how you manage your
database as i mentioned we have this notion of this offline catalog or definition of
the database that's expressed with sql statements but there's also
a subtlety of the two types of things there are there are the objects that define
what we're storing data in for example tables things that we use to look at the data
views and then we have programmable objects like stored procedures table value functions etc
you can bifurcate your management of those as well to where you allow developers to work
with a project that is just that subset you can do that with ssdt you can use it with uh the redgate tools
for example and so all these things require you to communicate and work out a plan
and this is independent of the tools right the tools will drive some of the decision making in actual mechanical
implementation but you have to coordinate this is where people have to talk
now one thing that people want to be able to do is update the app in the database
together and this can be done very easily with the tools i'm going to show you in simple cases but as you get to large
scale online 24 7 applications it gets complicated and so you often have to come up with a
plan where your application is resilient against different versions of the database a common approach here is that
we implement some type of versioning table and the application can check where it's at
in doing this you also have to think about updating the database and making sure
it's stable before you go forward and this is going back to that notion that the database isn't just code
it's code structure and ultimately that data and so with a lot of successful teams
that i've worked with the idea is that we get the database update out there the app continues to run against the
new version of the database it just ignores new fields and new values and then we update the app now once
again this gets very complex and ultimately what i'll tell you this is if you can
have an outage window to update your database take it doing online updates
with concurrent access to the system is much more complex it's doable but it really increases the
complexity so don't do it unless you actually have to now regardless of whether you use a
model-based approach or migration-based approach one thing you have to consider is data motion and data motion is the process of
dealing with structural changes of where the data is stored or how it's stored a common example
is to split up a field where you haven't maybe normalized it correctly and decide later that
a field that contains two pieces of data and the common examples you have a full name field and realize you want a
first name and surname field that type of operation is not usually magically happened by any
of the tools that i know of in fact this is the hardest problem so what you often have to do is think about
pre and post processing that occurs as you make that type of change ssdt for example supports pre and
post-processing scripts and one things that people often do is you know naturally do a full backup before you started the operations
but then you migrate some of the data into a temporary table change the table and then migrate the
data back as a secondary step this is not done automatically it requires you to use your brain
that's probably the big thing about using these type of tools they're not going to replace you or me
the reality is that these are complex problems that need to have people that understand the structure of the database and how the data works together
another issue is static data loading lots of databases have the standard business logic data
but then they have supporting lookup values everything from postal codes to geography information to
product codes that may not change as much on a regular basis as an example so look up data
that type of static data loading might be necessary as part of the process of doing a large scale
transformation on the database and again you can package those with your model or you can do it as a secondary step
and the last thing that really needs to be considered is we get into testing the changes to our database and
having good compliant test data one of the mistakes that i'll see a lot
is developers are given access to data out of production and if you work in a regulated industry
such as the financial sector or health care sector you really put yourself
and the organization in legal jeopardy by using production data that hasn't been properly
made compliant for developers to work with it so you want to look at this and this is
one of those areas where there are tools that are available some are quite expensive or you can
kind of bring your own tools to bear the key is that you don't want developers just taking random backups of the
production database now related to compliant test data is actually testing the database
and there are tools out there that will let you do testing uh t sql t is an example
that redgate supports with their sql test product uh tclt is open source and available for free the reality that
i found with doing database unit testing is that it often sounds good to everybody but
the reality is that it falls by the wayside and so what i tend to find works more
effectively because people actually do it is they wrap up their database testing as part of more functional testing of
an application plus the database i'm not saying if you can do database unit testing more power to you
you can do that during the build but the reality is that doing it well requires a lot of discipline and in my experience
over the last 10 15 years of working with this i don't see a lot of it people just find the complexity of doing
it right is is hard and part of that also goes back to that compliance on the test data so
keep all that in mind when you think about this part of your journey
